docs.lead_paragraph: There is a movement in more than a dozen states to outlaw a crucial element of health care reform: the requirement that everyone be insured or pay a penalty.

headline.seo: Lawmakers in Some States Press to Outlaw Mandatory Health Insurance
headline.main: Health Care Overhaul and Mandatory Coverage Stir States’ Rights Claims
headline.sub: State Lawmakers Push to Outlaw Insurance Mandate
headline.print_headline: Health Care Overhaul and Mandatory Coverage Stir States' Rights Claims

docs.snippet: There is a movement in more than a dozen states to outlaw a crucial element of health care reform: the requirement that everyone be insured or pay a penalty.

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Senate Finance Committee resumes debate Tuesday on its health care bill, a proposal for a government-run insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- will take center stage. Supporters say a public option would drive down the cost of private insurance. But the insurance industry opposes it, saying lower-priced government competition would put private insurance companies out of business.
docs.abstract: So-called public option will take center stage when Senate Finance Committee resumes debate on its health care bill; supporters say option would drive down cost of private insurance; insurance industry says lower-priced government competition would put private insurance companies out of business (S)
docs.snippet: When the Senate Finance Committee resumes debate Tuesday on its health care bill, a proposal for a government-run insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- will take center stage.      Supporters say a public option would drive down the cost...

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans are using a clip from President Obama's recent Sunday morning news media blitz to make a political point about the vocabulary of health care reform. In a Web video posted Monday, the Republican National Committee included part of a Sept. 20 interview in which George Stephanopoulos of ABC News cited a dictionary in asking Mr. Obama how requiring individuals to buy health insurance -- and fining them if they do not -- would not by definition be a tax.
docs.abstract: Republican National Committee posts Web video that includes part of September 20 inteview in which George Stephanopoulos of ABC News cites dictionary in asking Pres Obama how requiring individuals to buy health insurance, and fining them for not doing so, would not be considered tax (S)
